questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of chest pain. She describes the pain as intermittent and burning. She states that she has tried using proton pump inhibitors but has had no relief of her symptoms. She has had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 2 months. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg. Examination shows tightness of the skin of the fingers; there are small nonhealing, nonpurulent ulcers over thickened skin on the fingertips. Fine inspiratory crackles are heard at both lung bases. There is mild tenderness to palpation of the epigastrium. Which of the following findings is most likely to be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

c-ANCA are positive in approx. 90% of patients with granulomatosis with polyangiitis. Affected individuals usually have a history of chronic rhinosinusitis, ocular manifestations (scleritis, episcleritis, uveitis), ulcerating mucocutaneous granulomas, and/or vasculitic purpura.

B) CORRECT:

Antitopoisomerase I antibodies (anti-Scl-70) can be found in approx. 40% of individuals with diffuse SSc and indicate a poor prognosis and higher risk of severe interstitial lung disease. Further laboratory findings associated with diffuse SSc include antinuclear antibodies (approx. 90% of cases) and anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies. See “Overview of ANAs” table.

Anticentromere antibody is the main parameter for limited SSc which may also show positive testing for anti-Scl-70.

C) INCORRECT:

Antimitochondrial antibodies have a very high sensitivity and specificity for primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). This patient does not present with symptoms of PBC such as fatigue, generalized itching, and elevated cholestatic parameters.

D) INCORRECT:

Antihistone antibodies are characteristic for drug-induced lupus erythematosus and present in approx. 95% of cases. In this patient with symptoms of diffuse SSc, a different antibody is more likely to be found.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-Ro/SSA and/or anti-La/SSB antibodies are found in about 70% of individuals with Sjögren syndrome. Although Sjögren syndrome may also manifest with reflux esophagitis, respiratory complications, and similar skin manifestations (secondary to Raynaud phenomenon) in a middle-aged woman, it is also characterized by xerophthalmia and xerostomia (combination thereof known as Sicca syndrome), which are not present in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with typical findings of diffuse systemic sclerosis (SSc), including sclerodactyly (skin tightness and thickening, nonpurulent ulcers), pulmonary fibrosis (fine, inspiratory crackles), and gastroesophageal reflux disease (chest pain, weight loss) due to esophageal hypomotility.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 4-month history of lethargy. She has had joint pain for the past 15 years and does not have a primary care physician. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 132/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pallor of the oral mucosa and nontender subcutaneous nodules on both elbows. The distal interphalangeal joints of both hands are flexed and the proximal interphalangeal joints appear hyperextended. Range of motion in the fingers is restricted. The liver span is 6 cm and the spleen tip is palpated 4 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit
33%


Leukocyte count
1,800/mm3



Segmented neutrophils
35%


Lymphocytes
60%


Platelet count
130,000/mm3



Increased serum titers of which of the following is most specific for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Anti-cyclical citrullinated peptide antibodies (anti-CCP antibodies) are a highly specific marker for RA (specificity > 90%). High anti-CCP antibody titers are also associated with a more aggressive disease course (e.g., erosive arthritis or extra-articular manifestations, such as rheumatoid nodules and Felty syndrome). Although rare, Felty syndrome can occur in severe, long-standing, seropositive RA. Increased destruction of platelets and RBCs by the enlarged spleen (hypersplenism) results in thrombocytopenia and low hematocrit, which may be further aggravated by anemia of chronic disease.

See “Serological testing in rheumatoid arthritis” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-Smith antibodies (anti-Sm antibodies) are highly specific (≈ 90%) for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). SLE is more common among women and can manifest with arthralgia, anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and splenomegaly. However, joint deformities are uncommon (< 10% of cases), and leukopenia in patients with SLE is typically the result of lymphopenia, not neutropenia. Moreover, further symptoms such as myalgias, photosensitivity, and/or a malar rash would be expected in SLE. Anti-Sm antibodies are not associated with RA.

C) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) can be seen in approximately 30–50% of patients with RA. However, ANAs are also found in a number of other autoimmune disorders (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, inflammatory myopathies), and even in 25% of healthy individuals. Therefore, ANAs have low specificity for RA. Although the sensitivity of ANAs is higher in patients with RA and extra-articular manifestations (e.g., Felty syndrome), the specificity does not increase.

D) INCORRECT:

Although rheumatoid factor (RF) is present in 60–80% of patients with RA, this marker is not specific since it may also be seen in other autoimmune disorders (e.g., Sjogren syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, rheumatic fever), certain infectious diseases (e.g., syphilis, tuberculosis, infectious mononucleosis, infective endocarditis), sarcoidosis, pulmonary fibrosis, and/or chronic liver disease. RF can also be found in 3–5% of healthy individuals. The sensitivity of RF is higher in patients with RA and extra-articular manifestations (e.g., Felty syndrome), however, the specificity does not increase.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-U1 ribonucleoprotein antibodies (anti-U1 RNP antibodies) may be seen in 5–10% of patients with RA. However, anti-U1 RNP may also be seen in mixed connective tissue disease and occasionally in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, discoid lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Anti-U1 RNP antibodies are not a specific marker for RA.
questions.hint: A combination of chronic joint pain, swan neck deformities, subcutaneous nodules on the elbow (rheumatoid nodules), and Felty syndrome (arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia) in a middle-aged woman is consistent with rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of progressive weakness. She has had increased difficulty combing her hair and climbing stairs. She has hypertension. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. She does not drink alcohol. Her mother had coronary artery disease and systemic lupus erythematosus. Her current medications include chlorthalidone and vitamin supplements. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. A photograph of the patient's face is shown. Skin examination shows diffuse erythema of the upper back, posterior neck, and shoulders. Which of the following antibodies are most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-centromere antibodies are associated with systemic sclerosis (SSc), especially with limited cutaneous SSc, which may include CREST syndrome. The classic presentation of SSc involves thickening and hardening of the skin, sclerodactyly, Raynaud phenomenon, and gastrointestinal symptoms (dysphagia, reflux, etc). This patient's heliotrope rash and shawl sign are not consistent with SSc.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies are associated with Sjogren syndrome, an autoimmune disease involving the salivary and lacrimal glands. Patients with Sjogren syndrome typically present with dry mouth and dry eyes, and may also present with blurred vision, dysphagia, and dental caries. They can also have extraglandular symptoms, including fatigue, arthralgias, and the Raynaud phenomenon. Sjogren syndrome is not associated with a heliotrope rash or shawl sign, as seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-histone antibodies are a diagnostic marker of drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE). Common medications associated with DILE are procainamide and hydralazine, as well as isoniazid, quinidine, and sulfadiazine. DILE typically manifests with fever, polyarthritis, serositis, myalgia, and rash. This patient only takes chlorthalidone and vitamin supplements, however, and her rash is not typical for this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels are diagnostic of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). LEMS manifests with proximal muscle weakness that improves with repetitive use, and patients often have autonomic symptoms such as dry mouth, constipation, and orthostatic dysregulation. Rash is not a feature of LEMS.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

E) CORRECT:

Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are specific to both dermatomyositis and polymyositis. The presence of anti-Jo-1 antibodies is associated with a more aggressive disease course and an increased risk for interstitial lung disease. Anti-Mi-2 antibodies may also present and are typically associated with a more favorable prognosis. Dermatomyositis is associated with several malignancies, and all patients diagnosed with dermatomyositis should undergo age-appropriate malignancy screening.

F) INCORRECT:

Anti-myeloperoxidase antibodies (p-ANCA) are associated with microscopic polyangiitis and eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis. While these vasculitides may also involve the skin, classic findings are palpable purpura and/or skin nodules. They are not associated with a heliotrope rash or shawl sign, as seen in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Anti-Scl-70 antibodies (anti-topoisomerase) are associated with systemic sclerosis (SSc), especially with diffuse cutaneous SSc. In addition to the classic presentation of SSc, which includes sclerodactyly, Raynaud phenomenon, and gastrointestinal symptoms (dysphagia, reflux, etc), this subset is more likely to have proximal extremity involvement and is associated with an increased risk of developing interstitial lung disease. This patient's heliotrope rash and shawl sign are not consistent with SSc.
questions.hint: This patient's proximal muscle weakness, heliotrope rash, and shawl sign indicate dermatomyositis, an inflammatory myopathy (polymyositis) of the proximal skeletal muscles that is also characterized by skin involvement.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of sudden-onset fever, malaise, and pain and swelling of his wrists and ankles that began a week ago. One month ago, he was started on hydralazine for adjunctive treatment of hypertension. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F). Examination shows swelling, tenderness, warmth, and erythema of both wrists and ankles; range of motion is limited. Further evaluation is most likely to show an increased level of which of the following autoantibodies?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for SLE. These antibodies are rarely found in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-Smith antibodies are highly specific for SLE. These antibodies are rarely found in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-β2-glycoprotein antibodies are associated with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS), which can occur in patients with idiopathic SLE. APS is rare in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

D) CORRECT:

Anti-histone antibodies are present in most cases of drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE). Since anti-histone antibodies are a subtype of antinuclear antibodies (ANA), ANA will also be positive. Other common triggers of DILE include procainamide, sulfa drugs, methyldopa, isoniazid, and phenytoin. DILE can have many of the features of idiopathic SLE such as fever, arthritis, malar rash, and serositis. However, unlike idiopathic SLE, DILE does not affect the oral mucosa, brain, or kidneys and is typically self-limiting after discontinuation of the offending drug.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are associated with polymyositis and dermatomyositis, which manifest with symmetrical proximal muscle weakness. These antibodies are not typically found in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.
questions.hint: The onset of lupus-like symptoms (fever, malaise, polyarthritis) soon after starting hydralazine therapy indicates drug-induced lupus erythematosus. Idiopathic systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can manifest similarly but it is less common in men (90% of patients with idiopathic SLE are women) and is not associated with hydralazine therapy.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressive shortness of breath and difficulty swallowing. She can no longer take long walks with her dog because she gets out of breath easily. She has also had fatigue, muscle aches, and joint pain for 6 months. She says that her fingers recently started to become pale and numb in cold water, and warm and red on reheating. She does not smoke cigarettes and drinks one glass of wine weekly. Her pulse is 75/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention. There is swelling and tenderness of the metacarpophalangeal joints in both hands. Cardiac examination shows accentuation and splitting of S2. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.8 g/dL


Leukocyte count
4700/mm3



Platelet count
142,000/mm3



C-reactive protein
2.2 mg/L (N = 0.08–3.1)


Serum



Creatine kinase
66 U/L


Rheumatoid factor
positive


Antinuclear antibodies
positive


Anti-U1 RNP antibodies
positive


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) may manifest with findings that largely overlap with this patient's presentation (nonspecific features of autoimmune CTDs such as arthralgia, myalgia, pulmonary hypertension, and positive ANAs). Furthermore, the characteristic malar rash is not required for diagnosis. However, anti-dsDNA antibodies are typically associated with SLE, whereas anti-U1 RNP antibodies indicate a different CTD.

B) INCORRECT:

Sjogren syndrome may manifest with dysphagia (typically due to sicca syndrome) and nonspecific features of autoimmune CTDs such as positive rheumatoid factor. However, pulmonary involvement is uncommon in Sjogren syndrome. In addition, anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB antibodies are associated with Sjogren syndrome, whereas anti-U1 RNP antibodies indicate a different CTD.

C) INCORRECT:

Polymyositis may manifest with nonspecific features of autoimmune CTDs such as myalgia and positive ANAs. However, laboratory studies in patients with polymyositis typically show elevated creatine kinase (CK), whereas this patient's CK is within the reference range. Finally, anti-Jo-1 antibodies are associated with polymyositis, whereas anti-U1 RNP antibodies indicate a different CTD.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) may manifest with dysphagia and nonspecific features of autoimmune CTDs such as arthralgia, positive rheumatoid factor, pulmonary hypertension, and Raynaud phenomenon. However, in addition to dactylitis, features of sclerodactyly (atrophic and necrotic spots) would be expected on physical examination. In addition, anti-Scl-70 antibodies are typically associated with SSc, whereas anti-U1 RNP antibodies indicate a different CTD.

E) CORRECT:

A positive test for anti-U1 RNP antibodies (a type of ANA) is highly sensitive and specific for mixed connective tissue disorder (MCTD). Other autoantibodies, such as rheumatoid factor, may also be positive (see “Overview of ANAs” table). MCTD is characterized by concurrent features of at least two autoimmune connective tissue diseases, such as systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, or idiopathic inflammatory myopathies. Features of MCTD develop over months to years and include puffy fingers, synovitis, myositis, and Raynaud syndrome. This condition is diagnosed in patients with clinical features of MCTD and a positive anti-U1 RNP antibody test. Pulmonary hypertension and interstitial lung disease are the main causes of mortality in patients with MCTD.

F) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA), especially early-stage RA, may manifest with findings that greatly overlap with this patient's presentation (arthritis of the metacarpophalangeal joints, nonspecific features of autoimmune CTDs such as myalgia and positive rheumatoid factor). However, laboratory studies in patients with RA typically show an elevated C-reactive protein (CRP), whereas this patient's CRP is within the reference range. Moreover, anticitrullinated peptide antibodies are typically associated with RA, whereas anti-U1 RNP antibodies indicate a different CTD.
questions.hint: This patient presents with nonspecific features of an autoimmune connective tissue disease (CTD), including fatigue, myalgia, arthralgia, Raynaud syndrome, anemia, and positive antinuclear antibodies (ANAs), in addition to signs of pulmonary involvement, which has led to pulmonary hypertension (e.g., dyspnea, jugular venous distention, accentuated, split S2). However, the patient's antibody test is pathognomonic for a specific CTD.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 42 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I am tired and my joints hurt.”
History of Present Illness:


fatigue, myalgia, and joint pain over several years
joint pain rated 5/10 at worst

neck pain at rest most mornings, lasting more than an hour
occasionally wakes up at night with tingling in the right volar hand and thumb


Past Medical History:

no recent medical care in over a decade due to limited health care coverage
generalized anxiety disorder

Medications:
citalopram
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
mother and father alive with no chronic conditions
Psychosocial History:

has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years

does not drink alcoholic beverages
not sexually active

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
Ht
Wt
BMI


36.8°C(98.2°F)
87/min
14/min
142/85 mm Hg
164 cm(5 ft 5 in)
90 kg(198 lb)
33 kg/m2




Appearance: no acute distress
HEENT: conjunctival pallor; thyroid gland is normal in size with no mass or tenderness
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs
Musculoskeletal: flexion of proximal interphalangeal joints of bilateral index fingers with hyperextension of distal interphalangeal joints; tenderness and swelling in metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints of both hands and metatarsophalangeal joint of right 1st and 2nd toes

Neurologic: shooting pain along the right upper neck and shoulder with tilt and rotation of the neck toward the right side while applying downward pressure to the head

Diagnostic Studies


Blood



 Hemoglobin
10.1 g/dL


 WBC
4,200/mm3



 Platelet count
345,000/mm3



 ESR
42 mm/h



Testing for which of the following serum parameters is most likely to yield a positive result?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anticentromere antibodies are associated with limited systemic sclerosis (SSc). While limited SSc can manifest with arthralgia, myalgia, and constitutional symptoms, this patient has none of the characteristic features of this condition, such as calcinosis cutis, Raynaud phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia. Anticentromere antibodies are not associated with RA.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) antibodies are highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and can be found in 60–70% of affected individuals. SLE is more common in women and can manifest with distal symmetric polyarthritis, myalgia, neuropathy, anemia, and leukopenia. However, joint deformities are uncommon in SLE, and peripheral neuropathy is more likely than radicular neuropathy in these patients. Finally, additional symptoms consistent with SLE such as photosensitivity, Raynaud phenomenon, and/or a malar rash are absent in this patient. Anti-dsDNA antibodies are not associated with RA.

C) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibody (ANA) testing is commonly used to screen for autoimmune diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), certain types of inflammatory myopathies. ANAs are only elevated in 30–50% of patients with RA and are thus not a particularly useful screening test. A different serum study is more likely to be elevated in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor (RF) along with anticitrullinated peptide antibodies (ACPAs) are the most sensitive markers for RA and are present in 60–80% of patients. High RF and ACPA titers are also associated with a more aggressive disease course (e.g., erosive arthritis or extraarticular manifestations, such as rheumatoid nodules and Felty syndrome). The presence of RF is not specific for RA, however, and may also be seen in other autoimmune disorders (e.g., Sjogren syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatic fever), certain infectious diseases (e.g., parvovirus B19 infection, infective endocarditis), chronic liver disease, and even in 3–5% of healthy individuals. Approx. 30% of patients with RA are negative for ACPA and RF, referred to as seronegative RA.

See “Serological testing in rheumatoid arthritis” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-Mi2 antibodies are myositis-specific autoantibodies highly specific for dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis manifests with progressive symmetrical proximal muscle weakness and distinctive skin findings (e.g., Gottron papules, heliotrope rash), neither of which this patient has. Anti-Mi2 antibodies are not associated with RA.
questions.hint: Symmetric polyarthritis affecting the MCP, MTP, and PIP joints, along with Boutonniere deformities of bilateral index fingers, and features of cervical radiculopathy (due to atlantoaxial subluxation) strongly suggest rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue), compression syndromes (e.g., carpal tunnel syndrome), and anemia of chronic disease are common in patients with RA.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of progressive weakness. She has had increased difficulty combing her hair and climbing stairs. She has hypertension. Her current medications include chlorthalidone and vitamin supplements. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. A photograph of the patient's face is shown. Skin examination shows diffuse erythema of the upper back, posterior neck, and shoulders. Which of the following antibodies are most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-centromere antibodies are associated with systemic sclerosis (SSc), especially with limited cutaneous SSc, which may include CREST syndrome. The classic presentation of SSc involves thickening and hardening of the skin, sclerodactyly, Raynaud phenomenon, and gastrointestinal symptoms (dysphagia, reflux, etc). This patient's heliotrope rash and shawl sign are not consistent with SSc.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies are associated with Sjogren syndrome, an autoimmune disease involving the salivary and lacrimal glands. Patients with Sjogren syndrome typically present with dry mouth and dry eyes, and may also present with blurred vision, dysphagia, and dental caries. They can also have extraglandular symptoms, including fatigue, arthralgias, and the Raynaud phenomenon. Sjogren syndrome is not associated with a heliotrope rash or shawl sign, as seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-histone antibodies are a diagnostic marker of drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE). Common medications associated with DILE are procainamide and hydralazine, as well as isoniazid, quinidine, and sulfadiazine. DILE typically manifests with fever, polyarthritis, serositis, myalgia, and rash. This patient only takes chlorthalidone and vitamin supplements, however, and her rash is not typical for this diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are specific to both dermatomyositis and polymyositis. The presence of anti-Jo-1 antibodies is associated with a more aggressive disease course and an increased risk for interstitial lung disease. Anti-Mi-2 antibodies may also present and are typically associated with a more favorable prognosis. Dermatomyositis is associated with several malignancies, and all patients diagnosed with dermatomyositis should undergo age-appropriate malignancy screening.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-Scl-70 antibodies (anti-topoisomerase) are associated with systemic sclerosis (SSc), especially with diffuse cutaneous SSc. In addition to the classic presentation of SSc, which includes sclerodactyly, Raynaud phenomenon, and gastrointestinal symptoms (dysphagia, reflux, etc), this subset is more likely to have proximal extremity involvement and is associated with an increased risk of developing interstitial lung disease. This patient's heliotrope rash and shawl sign are not consistent with SSc.
questions.hint: This patient's proximal muscle weakness, heliotrope rash, and shawl sign indicate dermatomyositis, an inflammatory myopathy (polymyositis) of the proximal skeletal muscles that is also characterized by skin involvement.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to the office with a 4-month history of lethargy. She has had progressive pain and stiffness in her hands and wrists for the past 15 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows pallor of the oral mucosa and nontender subcutaneous nodules on both elbows. The distal interphalangeal joints of both hands are flexed and the proximal interphalangeal joints appear hyperextended. Range of motion in the fingers is restricted. Increased serum titers of which of the following is most specific for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Anti-cyclical citrullinated peptide antibodies (anti-CCP antibodies) are a highly specific marker for RA (specificity > 90%). High anti-CCP antibody titers are also associated with a more aggressive disease course (e.g., erosive arthritis or extra-articular manifestations, such as rheumatoid nodules and Felty syndrome).

See “Serological testing in rheumatoid arthritis” table.

Key learning point: Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies are the most specific serological marker for rheumatoid arthritis, with specificity greater than 90%.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-Smith antibodies (anti-Sm antibodies) are highly specific (≈ 90%) for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). SLE is more common among women and can manifest with arthralgia. However, joint deformities are uncommon (< 10% of cases). Moreover, further symptoms such as myalgias, photosensitivity, and/or a malar rash would be expected in SLE. Anti-Sm antibodies are not associated with RA.

C) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) can be seen in approximately 30–50% of patients with RA. However, ANAs are also found in a number of other autoimmune disorders (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, inflammatory myopathies), and even in 25% of healthy individuals. Therefore, ANAs have low specificity for RA.

D) INCORRECT:

Although rheumatoid factor (RF) is present in 60–80% of patients with RA, this marker is not specific since it may also be seen in other autoimmune disorders (e.g., Sjogren syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, rheumatic fever), certain infectious diseases (e.g., syphilis, tuberculosis, infectious mononucleosis, infective endocarditis), sarcoidosis, pulmonary fibrosis, and/or chronic liver disease. RF can also be found in 3–5% of healthy individuals.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-U1 ribonucleoprotein antibodies (anti-U1 RNP antibodies) may be seen in 5–10% of patients with RA. However, anti-U1 RNP may also be seen in mixed connective tissue disease and occasionally in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, discoid lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Anti-U1 RNP antibodies are not a specific marker for RA.
questions.hint: A combination of chronic joint pain, swan neck deformity of the fingers, and subcutaneous nodules on the elbow (rheumatoid nodules) in a middle-aged woman is consistent with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the office because of sudden-onset fever, malaise, and pain and swelling of his wrists and ankles that began a week ago. One month ago, he was started on hydralazine for adjunctive treatment of hypertension. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F). Examination shows swelling, tenderness, warmth, and erythema of both wrists and ankles; range of motion is limited. Further evaluation is most likely to show an increased level of which of the following autoantibodies?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for SLE. These antibodies are rarely found in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-Smith antibodies are highly specific for SLE. These antibodies are rarely found in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-β2-glycoprotein antibodies are associated with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS), which can occur in patients with idiopathic SLE. APS is rare in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

D) CORRECT:

Anti-histone antibodies are present in most cases of drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE). Since anti-histone antibodies are a subtype of antinuclear antibodies (ANA), ANA will also be positive. Other common triggers of DILE include procainamide, sulfa drugs, methyldopa, isoniazid, and phenytoin. DILE can have many of the features of idiopathic SLE such as fever, arthritis, malar rash, and serositis. However, unlike idiopathic SLE, DILE does not affect the oral mucosa, brain, or kidneys and is typically self-limiting after discontinuation of the offending drug.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are associated with polymyositis and dermatomyositis, which manifest with symmetrical proximal muscle weakness. These antibodies are not typically found in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.
questions.hint: The onset of lupus-like symptoms (fever, malaise, polyarthritis) soon after starting hydralazine therapy indicates drug-induced lupus erythematosus. Idiopathic systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can manifest similarly but it is less common in men (90% of patients with idiopathic SLE are women) and is not associated with hydralazine therapy.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-week history of progressive weakness. She reports increasing difficulty combing her hair and climbing stairs. She has a history of hypertension and is currently taking chlorthalidone and vitamin supplements. Her temperature is 37.8°C, pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. A photograph of her face is provided. On skin examination, there is diffuse erythema over the upper back, posterior neck, and shoulders. Which one of the following antibodies is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-centromere antibodies are associated with systemic sclerosis (SSc), especially with limited cutaneous SSc, which may include CREST syndrome. The classic presentation of SSc involves thickening and hardening of the skin, sclerodactyly, Raynaud phenomenon, and gastrointestinal symptoms (dysphagia, reflux, etc). This patient's heliotrope rash and shawl sign are not consistent with SSc.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-Scl-70 antibodies (anti-topoisomerase) are associated with systemic sclerosis (SSc), especially with diffuse cutaneous SSc. In addition to the classic presentation of SSc, which includes sclerodactyly, Raynaud phenomenon, and gastrointestinal symptoms (dysphagia, reflux, etc), this subset is more likely to have proximal extremity involvement and is associated with an increased risk of developing interstitial lung disease. This patient's heliotrope rash and shawl sign are not consistent with SSc.

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies are associated with Sjogren syndrome, an autoimmune disease involving the salivary and lacrimal glands. Patients with Sjogren syndrome typically present with dry mouth and dry eyes, and may also present with blurred vision, dysphagia, and dental caries. They can also have extraglandular symptoms, including fatigue, arthralgias, and the Raynaud phenomenon. Sjogren syndrome is not associated with a heliotrope rash or shawl sign, as seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are specific to both dermatomyositis and polymyositis. The presence of anti-Jo-1 antibodies is associated with a more aggressive disease course and an increased risk for interstitial lung disease. Anti-Mi-2 antibodies may also present and are typically associated with a more favorable prognosis. Dermatomyositis is associated with several malignancies, and all patients diagnosed with dermatomyositis should undergo age-appropriate malignancy screening.

Key learning point: Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are specific for dermatomyositis and polymyositis and are associated with increased risk of interstitial lung disease and a more aggressive disease course.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-histone antibodies are a diagnostic marker of drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE). Common medications associated with DILE are procainamide and hydralazine, as well as isoniazid, quinidine, and sulfadiazine. DILE typically manifests with fever, polyarthritis, serositis, myalgia, and rash. This patient only takes chlorthalidone and vitamin supplements, however, and her rash is not typical for this diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient's proximal muscle weakness, heliotrope rash, and shawl sign indicate dermatomyositis, an inflammatory myopathy (polymyositis) of the proximal skeletal muscles that is also characterized by skin involvement.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 4-month history of lethargy. She reports progressive pain and stiffness in her hands and wrists over the past 15 years. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there is pallor of the oral mucosa and nontender subcutaneous nodules on both elbows. The distal interphalangeal joints of both hands are flexed, and the proximal interphalangeal joints appear hyperextended. Finger range of motion is restricted. Increased serum titers of which one of the following is most specific for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) can be seen in approximately 30–50% of patients with RA. However, ANAs are also found in a number of other autoimmune disorders (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, inflammatory myopathies), and even in 25% of healthy individuals. Therefore, ANAs have low specificity for RA.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-Smith antibodies (anti-Sm antibodies) are highly specific (≈ 90%) for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). SLE is more common among women and can manifest with arthralgia. However, joint deformities are uncommon (< 10% of cases). Moreover, further symptoms such as myalgias, photosensitivity, and/or a malar rash would be expected in SLE. Anti-Sm antibodies are not associated with RA.

C) INCORRECT:

Although rheumatoid factor (RF) is present in 60–80% of patients with RA, this marker is not specific since it may also be seen in other autoimmune disorders (e.g., Sjogren syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, rheumatic fever), certain infectious diseases (e.g., syphilis, tuberculosis, infectious mononucleosis, infective endocarditis), sarcoidosis, pulmonary fibrosis, and/or chronic liver disease. RF can also be found in 3–5% of healthy individuals.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-U1 ribonucleoprotein antibodies (anti-U1 RNP antibodies) may be seen in 5–10% of patients with RA. However, anti-U1 RNP may also be seen in mixed connective tissue disease and occasionally in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, discoid lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Anti-U1 RNP antibodies are not a specific marker for RA.

E) CORRECT:

Anti-cyclical citrullinated peptide antibodies (anti-CCP antibodies) are a highly specific marker for RA (specificity > 90%). High anti-CCP antibody titers are also associated with a more aggressive disease course (e.g., erosive arthritis or extra-articular manifestations, such as rheumatoid nodules and Felty syndrome).

See “Serological testing in rheumatoid arthritis” table.

Key learning point: Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies are the most specific serological marker for rheumatoid arthritis, with specificity greater than 90%.
questions.hint: A combination of chronic joint pain, swan neck deformity of the fingers, and subcutaneous nodules on the elbow (rheumatoid nodules) in a middle-aged woman is consistent with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to your clinic with sudden-onset fever, malaise, and pain and swelling of his wrists and ankles that began one week ago. One month ago, he started hydralazine as adjunctive treatment for hypertension. His temperature is 37.8°C. On examination, both wrists and ankles are swollen, tender, warm, and erythematous, with limited range of motion. Further evaluation is most likely to show an increased level of which one of the following autoantibodies?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-β2-glycoprotein antibodies are associated with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS), which can occur in patients with idiopathic SLE. APS is rare in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for SLE. These antibodies are rarely found in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are associated with polymyositis and dermatomyositis, which manifest with symmetrical proximal muscle weakness. These antibodies are not typically found in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-Smith antibodies are highly specific for SLE. These antibodies are rarely found in patients with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

E) CORRECT:

Anti-histone antibodies are present in most cases of drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE). Since anti-histone antibodies are a subtype of antinuclear antibodies (ANA), ANA will also be positive. Other common triggers of DILE include procainamide, sulfa drugs, methyldopa, isoniazid, and phenytoin. DILE can have many of the features of idiopathic SLE such as fever, arthritis, malar rash, and serositis. However, unlike idiopathic SLE, DILE does not affect the oral mucosa, brain, or kidneys and is typically self-limiting after discontinuation of the offending drug.

Key learning point: Drug-induced lupus erythematosus is most strongly associated with anti-histone antibodies and typically resolves after discontinuing the offending medication.
questions.hint: The onset of lupus-like symptoms (fever, malaise, polyarthritis) soon after starting hydralazine therapy indicates drug-induced lupus erythematosus. Idiopathic systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can manifest similarly but it is less common in men (90% of patients with idiopathic SLE are women) and is not associated with hydralazine therapy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of low-grade fever, joint pain, and muscle aches. The day before the onset of her symptoms, she was severely sunburned on her face and arms during a hike with friends. She also reports being unusually fatigued over the past 3 months. Her only medication is a combined oral contraceptive pill. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F). Examination shows bilateral swelling and tenderness of the wrists and metacarpophalangeal joints. There are multiple nontender superficial ulcers on the oral mucosa. The detection of antibodies directed against which of the following is most specific for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibodies directed against myeloperoxidase (i.e., perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody, p-ANCA) play no role in the diagnosis of SLE. This type of antibody is used to diagnose individuals with microscopic polyangiitis, which can present with fever, fatigue, myalgia, arthralgia, and oral ulcers. However, microscopic polyangiitis is not associated with photosensitivity. It is usually associated with palpable purpura and hemoptysis, neither of which is seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Antibodies targeting the cell nucleus (i.e., anti-nuclear antibodies, ANA) are very sensitive marker (∼ 95%) for SLE. However, it is a nonspecific marker that is seen in many other conditions (i.e., systemic sclerosis, Sjögren syndrome, polymyositis, dermatomyositis, and even in healthy individuals). The presence of ANA in serum necessitates further testing to determine the etiology of the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibodies directed against single-stranded DNA (i.e., anti-ssDNA antibodies) are not used to confirm the diagnosis of SLE. This particular type of antibody can be found in patients with SLE, but it is not specific enough to be diagnostic.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibodies directed against the Fc region of IgG (i.e., rheumatoid factor) are present in ∼ one-third of SLE patients. Rheumatoid factor is not specific enough to be of diagnostic value, but it is a moderately sensitive test for the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis, which can manifest with low-grade fever, swelling, and tenderness of the wrists and metacarpophalangeal joints. It is not associated with multiple oral ulcers or photosensitivity.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibodies directed against phospholipid-binding proteins (i.e., antiphospholipid antibodies) are found in 30–40% of patients with SLE. Of those with antiphospholipid antibodies, about 20% will go on to develop antiphospholipid antibody syndrome. Screening for this type of antibody is therefore important in patients with SLE. However, it does not have any diagnostic value for SLE.

F) CORRECT:

Antibodies to nuclear Sm proteins (i.e., anti-Smith antibodies) are a highly specific marker for SLE. However, they are only positive in 30% of patients, meaning they are not a very sensitive marker. For this reason, the diagnosis of SLE is always based on clinical features as well as immunologic test results. Another highly specific antibody for the diagnosis of SLE targets double-stranded DNA. Anti-dsDNA antibodies are present in 70% of patients with SLE (high sensitivity), correlate with disease activity, and are associated with lupus nephritis.

See “Overview of antinuclear antibodies” table.

G) INCORRECT:

Antibodies directed against histones (i.e., antihistone antibodies) are found in nearly 95% of patients with drug-induced lupus. This woman's only medication (OCP) does not cause drug-induced lupus and she has no history of taking any drugs that cause it (e.g., sulfonamides, hydralazine, isoniazid, procainamide, or phenytoin). Antihistone antibodies can be seen in SLE; however, they are far more common in drug-induced lupus.
questions.hint: This patient's fever, arthritis, increased photosensitivity, and painless oral ulcers are highly suggestive of a diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
